flixel.util.FlxPath

type
class
This is a simple path data container. Basically a list of points that a FlxObject can follow. Also has code for drawing debug visuals. FlxTilemap.findPath() returns a path object, but you can also just make your own, using the add() functions below or by creating your own array of points.

Static Variables

BACKWARD(inline,null) : Int

Path behavior controls: move from the end of the path to the start then stop.

FORWARD(inline,null) : Int

Path behavior controls: move from the start of the path to the end then stop.

HORIZONTAL_ONLY(inline,null) : Int

Path behavior controls: ignores any vertical component to the path data, only follows side to side.

LOOP_BACKWARD(inline,null) : Int

Path behavior controls: move from the end of the path to the start then directly back to the end, and start over.

LOOP_FORWARD(inline,null) : Int

Path behavior controls: move from the start of the path to the end then directly back to the start, and start over.

VERTICAL_ONLY(inline,null) : Int

Path behavior controls: ignores any horizontal component to the path data, only follows up and down.

YOYO(inline,null) : Int

Path behavior controls: move from the start of the path to the end then turn around and go back to the start, over and over.

manager : flixel.plugin.PathManager

Read-only: The TimerManager instance.

Static Methods

put(path : FlxPath) : Void

recycle() : FlxPath

Returns a recycled path.

start(Object : flixel.FlxObject, Nodes : Array<FlxPoint>, ?Speed : Float, ?Mode : Int, ?AutoRotate : Bool, ?UsePooling : Bool) : FlxPath

parameters
Object The Object which will follow this path
Nodes Array of points which will construct path.
Speed How fast to travel along the path in pixels per second.
Mode Optional, controls the behavior of the object following the path using the path behavior constants. Can use multiple flags at once, for example PATH_YOYO|PATH_HORIZONTAL_ONLY will make an object move back and forth along the X axis of the path only.
AutoRotate Automatically point the object toward the next node. Assumes the graphic is pointing upward. Default behavior is false, or no automatic rotation.
Call this function to give this object a path to follow. If the path does not have at least one node in it, this function will log a warning message and return.

Constructor

new()
Instantiate a new path object.

Instance Variables

angle : Float

The angle in degrees between this object and the next node, where 0 is directly upward, and 90 is to the right.

autoCenter : Bool

Whether the object should auto-center the path or at its origin.

debugColor : Int

Specify a debug display color for the path. Default is white.

debugScrollX : Float

Specify a debug display scroll factor for the path. Default is (1,1). NOTE: does not affect world movement! Object scroll factors take care of that.

debugScrollY : Float

finished(default,null) : Bool

ignoreDrawDebug : Bool

Setting this to true will prevent the object from appearing when the visual debug mode in the debugger overlay is toggled on.

nodes : Array<FlxPoint>

The list of FlxPoints that make up the path data.

object : flixel.FlxObject

Object which will follow this path

onComplete : FlxPath -> Void

paused : Bool

Pauses or checks the pause state of the timer.

speed : Float

The speed at which the object is moving on the path. When an object completes a non-looping path circuit, the pathSpeed will be zeroed out, but the path reference will NOT be nulled out. So pathSpeed is a good way to check if this object is currently following a path or not.

usePooling : Bool

Instance Methods

abort() : Void

Stops path movement and removes this path it from the path manager.

add(X : Float, Y : Float) : FlxPath

parameters
X X position of the new path point in world coordinates.
Y Y position of the new path point in world coordinates.
Add a new node to the end of the path at the specified location.

addAt(X : Float, Y : Float, Index : Int) : FlxPath

parameters
X X position of the new path point in world coordinates.
Y Y position of the new path point in world coordinates.
Index Where within the list of path nodes to insert this new point.
Add a new node to the path at the specified location and index within the path.

addPoint(Node : FlxPoint, ?AsReference : Bool) : FlxPath

parameters
Node The point in world coordinates you want to add to the path.
AsReference Whether to add the point as a reference, or to create a new point with the specified values.
Sometimes its easier or faster to just pass a point object instead of separate X and Y coordinates. This also gives you the option of not creating a new node but actually adding that specific FlxPoint object to the path. This allows you to do neat things, like dynamic paths.

addPointAt(Node : FlxPoint, Index : Int, ?AsReference : Bool) : FlxPath

parameters
Node The point in world coordinates you want to add to the path.
Index Where within the list of path nodes to insert this new point.
AsReference Whether to add the point as a reference, or to create a new point with the specified values.
Sometimes its easier or faster to just pass a point object instead of separate X and Y coordinates. This also gives you the option of not creating a new node but actually adding that specific FlxPoint object to the path. This allows you to do neat things, like dynamic paths.

destroy() : Void

Clean up memory.

drawDebug(?Camera : flixel.FlxCamera) : Void

parameters
Camera The camera object the path will draw to.
While this doesn't override FlxBasic.drawDebug(), the behavior is very similar. Based on this path data, it draws a simple lines-and-boxes representation of the path if the visual debug mode was toggled in the debugger overlay. You can use debugColor and debugScrollFactor to control the path's appearance.

head() : FlxPoint

returns
The first node in the path.
Get the first node in the list.

remove(Node : FlxPoint) : FlxPoint

parameters
Node The point object you want to remove from the path.
returns
The node that was excised. Returns null if the node was not found.
Remove a node from the path. NOTE: only works with points added by reference or with references from nodes itself!

removeAt(Index : Int) : FlxPoint

parameters
Index Where within the list of path nodes you want to remove a node.
returns
The node that was excised. Returns null if there were no nodes in the path.
Remove a node from the path using the specified position in the list of path nodes.

reset() : FlxPath

parameters
Object
Nodes Optional, can specify all the points for the path up front if you want.
returns

restart() : FlxPath

run(Object : flixel.FlxObject, Nodes : Array<FlxPoint>, ?Speed : Float, ?Mode : Int, ?AutoRotate : Bool, ?UsePooling : Bool) : FlxPath

setNode(NodeIndex : Int) : Void

parameters
NodeIndex The index of the new node out of path.nodes.
Change the path node this object is currently at.

tail() : FlxPoint

returns
The last node in the path.
Get the last node in the list.

update() : Void

Internal function for moving the object along the path. Generally this function is called automatically by preUpdate(). The first half of the function decides if the object can advance to the next node in the path, while the second half handles actually picking a velocity toward the next node.
